Title.evidence: This randomized controlled trial did not demonstrate the superiority of paravertebral over epidural analgesia regarding the quality of recovery on POD3 after MIE.

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomized controlled superiority trial was conducted across 4 Dutch centers with esophageal cancer patients scheduled for transthoracic MIE with intrathoracic anastomosis, randomizing patients to receive either epidural or paravertebral analgesia.

Participants.evidence: esophageal cancer patients scheduled for transthoracic MIE with intrathoracic anastomosis

Intervention.evidence: randomizing patients to receive either epidural or paravertebral analgesia.

Objective.evidence: To compare the quality of recovery in patients receiving epidural or paravertebral analgesia for minimally invasive esophagectomy (MIE).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was Quality of Recovery (QoR-40) on the third postoperative day (POD).

Number_Randomised.evidence: From December 2019 to February 2023, 192 patients were included: 94 received epidural and 98 paravertebral analgesia.

Number_Analysed.evidence: QoR-40 score on POD3 was not different between groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: QoR-40 score on POD3 was not different between groups (mean difference: 3.7, 95% CI: −2.3 to 9.7; P =0.268).

Harms.evidence: More epidural patients required vasopressor medication on POD1 (38.3% vs 13.3%; P <0.001).
